Turing Award

Winner: Marvin Minsky

Why the Turing Award?

Minsky's reasearches focused on the concept of Artificial Intelligence . He is in fact considered worthy of receiving the Turing Award for "his central role in creating, shaping, promoting, and advancing the field of artificial intelligence".
His inventions were remarkable, and they were perceived as futuristic by people; among other things, he invented the SNARC (1951), the Confocal Scanning Microscope (1955), the Serpentine Hydraulic Robot Arm (1967) and the first head-mounted graphical display in history (1963).

More on his work

Minksy's work contributed a lot in theoretical and practical advances in artificial intelligence, as well as neural networks and cognitive psychology.

SNARC

SNARC stands for "Stochastic Neural Analog Reinforcement Calculator". it is the first self-learning Neural Network Simulator: in fact, when "rewarded" it facilitated recently-used pathways. It was based on the reinforcement of simulated synaptic transmission coefficients.

Confocal Scanning Microscope

This machine's purpose is to increase the contrast and the optical resolution of a micrograph. Moving the stage, it was possible to scan the illumination point in the focal plane. The invention of Minsky became popular because of his unprecedented resolution and image clarity.

Serpentine Hydraulic Robot Arm

Also known as Tentacle Arm or Minsky Arm , this robotic arm had movement that reminded the ones of an octopus, and it was designed to be mounted on a wall and reach around obtacles; it could lift the weight corresponding to a person. Today, the original one can be found in the Boston Museum of Science.

Head-mounted graphical display

The Head-mounted display (also HMD) is a device that is tipically worn on the head and has two small display optic, one in front on each eye. The first of these devices was invented five years before the well-known Sword of Damocles, that was created in 1968.
